original_title: World Heart Day: ‘Don’t miss a beat’
original_body_lines: World Heart Day falls on 29 September each year. This day is a new opportunity to reflect on how to best use the heart for the benefit of humanity and nature. Defeating cardiovascular disease (heart attack and stroke) is something that concerns all hearts in the world.
This year’s campaign is “Don’t Miss a Beat” and this official theme is announced and approved by the World Heart Federation (WHF) for 2025.
WHF, which was founded in 1978, is a non-governmental organisation based in Geneva, Switzerland. The goal of this theme is to encourage people to take care of their hearts.
Heart disease and strokes are the leading cause of death, claiming 20.5 million deaths every year.
According to WHO (World Heart Organisation) statistics, 82% of all deaths occur in low- and middle-income countries due to lack of resources.
Cardiovascular disease continues to be the number one cause of death and disability in the world today.
According to WHF, up to 80% of premature deaths from heart attacks and strokes can be prevented with access to care, early screening, and healthier lifestyle changes.
Every year on 29th September, people all over the world celebrate Heart Day as a way to draw attention to cardiovascular illnesses and their management.

Global leaders have recognised the urgency to give priority to prevention and control of heart disease with other non-communicable diseases (NCD) which include diabetes, cancer, and chronic lung disease.
Get Active – Physical activities such as walking, running or cycling and encourage others to join you.
Events – Local health fairs, walks, public talks, podcasts, fundraisers and sporting events, cardiovascular screenings or seminars that focus on cardiovascular health and preventive strategies.
Cardiovascular disease is a combination of diseases in heart and blood vessels.

Unhealthy diet, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, diabetes, reduced physical activity, heavy smoking, air pollution, harmful use of alcohol, stress and anxiety state, strong family history. Ethnic background, sex and age can also affect a person’s risk of CVD.
In WHO South East region, for instance, CVD account for 3.9 million deaths annually, nearly half of these are before age 70.
We request people to take charge of their heart health by taking the following steps to reduce risk of CVD:

Stopping smoking at home will improve children’s heart health and also it dramatically reduces the risk of heart attacks, strokes, and sudden death. Strong motivation will need to quit smoking. Medical assistance will also help to support this.

Unhealthy diet is the cause of many health issues, especially obesity, diabetes and cardiovascular diseases. Rapid urbanisation, changing the lifestyle and easy access to fast foods have made dietary patterns unhealthy.

Trans fats are the worst type of fat we can eat. It reduces HDL-C (good cholesterol) and raises LDL cholesterol (bad cholesterol). This can make heart attacks or strokes more likely. Most trans fats are formed through a manufacturing process adding hydrogen to vegetable oils, which causes the oil to become solid at room temperature.

Processed foods like baked (cookies, cakes and crackers), fried food (French fries, doughnuts), muffins, sausages, non-dairy creamer, burgers, pizza, margarine spread or peanut butter, and any type of deep-fried foods carry trans fats.
Eg: Olive, peanuts, sunflower, and canola oil, avocado, almond, walnuts, and other nuts, fatty fish.
Moderate physical activity like brisk walking and gardening for at least 150 minutes per week with muscle strengthening activities two days a week.
Use a smaller plate – eating a small portion with a single serving.
excessive drinking can lead to high blood pressure, heart diseases, strokes, liver disease, and various cancers.
– stress can cause arteries to tighten, thereby increasing heart rate.

Elevation of blood pressure, and release of stress hormones (adrenaline) which can increase risk of heart disease, especially in women. Exercise, deep breathing, and relaxing your muscles and meditation, adequate sleep, various hobbies, listening to music, talking about your problem with your close friends, and being with your family and friends making time for the things you love are some facts to help manage stress levels.
Asian specific cutoffs are lower because they are more predictive of health risks such as diabetes and cardiovascular disease in Asian population compared to the global standard.
​(Global standards define overweight as a BMI of 25-29.9 kg/m² and obesity > 30 kg/m²)
​In Asian regions (India and Sri Lanka) BMI of 23 kg/m² is considered the threshold for overweight with normal range from 18.5 to 22.9 kg/m².
​In Sri Lanka, underweight is <18.5 kg/m², normal 18.5-22.9 kg/m², overweight/obesity is >23 kg/m².
Know your Blood pressure which is a risk factor for CVD. Check regularly and control it with medication and exercise.
Know your cholesterol – High cholesterol is another major risk factor for CVD. It should be checked regularly and control with dietary measures and medication.
Know your Blood sugar – Diabetes is a very high risk for CVD. Diet control and medication required to control it.
Recognising symptoms of CVD can help you survive because earlier the treatment better the chance of survival.

a) Chest pain of tightening or burning in nature with pain radiating down the upper limb or towards the jaw or back associated with sweating and nausea is the typical presentation of Heart attacks. Sometimes heartburn or burning tummy pain could be due to a heart attack rather than gastritis or indigestion.

(b) Sudden weakness of limbs, slurring of speech, deviating of mouth to a side, numbness of face, limbs, or double vision could be due to a stroke. Knowing their symptoms and seeking medical assistance allows you to get treatment early and prevent complication which can be life-threatening most of the time.
If you are already diagnosed with a Heart disease or stroke, taking your medicine without fail will reduce the chance of getting another attack of Stroke or Heart disease.
Breast feeding is the best form of nutrition for new born and infants to have lower cholesterol and Blood pressure as well as lower rate of overweight and obesity all of which improve cardiac health.
Evidence suggest that new borns who are undernourished while in uterus bear a higher CVD risk later in life.
Maternal obesity during pregnancy has been associated with obesity in children which increases risk of CVD in later life.
By doing these household steps above, you and your family can reduce burden of heart disease and strokes.
People all over the world can have longer and better life style through prevention and control of heart disease and stroke.

World Heart day’s theme “Don’t Miss a Beat” is not just inspirational slogans – they are calls to urgent concrete actions with the right policies, community support, health system capacity and individual commitment.
Stay happy and healthy, warm wishes on World Heart Day for a heart that only knows love, laughter and longevity
